cost_objections.objection: Your engineering fees seem high compared to [competitor/expectation]
cost_objections.wrong_response: You get what you pay for / We're worth it / Our quality is better
cost_objections.authentic_response: Let's talk about what's included in our scope versus theirs. Are they providing [specific deliverables like site visits, construction administration, code research, coordination with other disciplines]? The difference often isn't in hourly rates but in the thoroughness of analysis and documentation. What specific deliverables are most important for your project's success?
cost_objections.reframe: The engineering fee is typically 3-8% of construction costs. A thorough design that prevents change orders and ensures constructability can save 10-20x the engineering investment. Where have you seen costs balloon on past projects?
cost_objections.underlying_fear: Wasting money or getting taken advantage of due to technical knowledge gap

timeline_objections.objection: We need this done faster than your proposed timeline
timeline_objections.wrong_response: We can rush it for an extra fee / That's just how long it takes
timeline_objections.authentic_response: I understand timeline pressure - let's look at what's driving the schedule. The analysis phase requires [X] time for proper load calculations, code review, and coordination. We can potentially compress [specific phase] if we [specific accommodation]. What's the consequence of the current timeline versus a faster but potentially incomplete analysis?
timeline_objections.reframe: What typically causes delays is rework from incomplete initial designs. We can fast-track specific elements, but cutting corners on [structural calculations/load analysis/code compliance] usually adds time on the back end through RFIs, change orders, or plan review rejections. Which parts of the timeline are truly immovable?
timeline_objections.underlying_fear: Project delays causing financial losses or missed opportunities

expertise_objections.objection: Have you actually done this specific type of project before?
expertise_objections.wrong_response: We can figure it out / All projects are different anyway
expertise_objections.authentic_response: That's exactly the right question to ask. We've designed [X similar projects] including [specific relevant example]. What's unique about your project is [specific aspect]. Here's how our experience with [related challenge] applies, and here's where we'd bring in [specific expertise/subconsultant] to address [specialized requirement]. What specific aspects are you most concerned about?
expertise_objections.reframe: The principles of [structural engineering/MEP design/civil engineering] are consistent, but you're right that application matters. Let me walk you through a similar project where we handled [specific challenge comparable to theirs] and how that experience translates to your situation.
expertise_objections.underlying_fear: Becoming a learning experiment for the engineer at their expense

scope_objections.objection: We don't need all of that - can't you just stamp the drawings?
scope_objections.wrong_response: That would be illegal / We don't work that way
scope_objections.authentic_response: I understand wanting to minimize costs and scope. Here's the challenge: my PE license requires that I take professional responsibility for any work I seal. That means I need to personally verify [calculations/site conditions/code compliance]. If something fails, I'm liable - and more importantly, so are you. What I can do is clearly break down what's legally required for the stamp versus what's optional value-add. Then you can make an informed decision about risk versus cost.
scope_objections.reframe: Let's separate what you legally need from what would be beneficial. For the PE stamp, I must verify [specific requirements]. Beyond that, [additional scope items] would reduce risk of [specific problems], but aren't strictly required. What level of risk are you comfortable with?
scope_objections.underlying_fear: Paying for unnecessary services due to lack of technical knowledge

relationship_objections.objection: We've always used [current engineer] - why should we switch?
relationship_objections.wrong_response: We're better than them / They're doing it wrong
relationship_objections.authentic_response: Loyalty to a trusted partner makes complete sense - that relationship has value. I'm not suggesting you abandon that. What I'm hearing is that this particular project has [specific challenge] that might benefit from [our specific expertise]. Many of our clients use us for specialized situations while maintaining their primary engineering relationships. Would it make sense to bring us in just for [specific technical aspect] while your current engineer handles the rest?
relationship_objections.reframe: The best engineering teams know when to bring in specialists. This isn't about replacing your current engineer - it's about ensuring this specific challenge gets the specialized attention it needs. How has your current firm handled [similar technical challenge] in the past?
relationship_objections.underlying_fear: Disrupting working relationships and having to rebuild trust with new consultant

diy_objections.objection: We have an engineer on staff - we might just handle this internally
diy_objections.wrong_response: Your person isn't qualified / You need us instead
diy_objections.authentic_response: Having internal engineering capability is valuable. The question is usually about capacity and specialization rather than competence. Is your internal engineer a licensed PE in [required specialty]? Do they have availability given their other responsibilities? Many companies use us to supplement their internal team during peak periods or for specialized analysis outside their primary focus. How is your internal engineer's bandwidth right now?
diy_objections.reframe: We often work alongside internal engineering teams - they maintain project control and institutional knowledge while we provide specialized analysis, PE stamps for specific disciplines, or surge capacity. That way your engineer isn't pulled away from strategic work. What would free up your internal person to focus on?
diy_objections.underlying_fear: Admitting they need outside help or wasting internal resources

thread_structure: Everyone talks about carbon footprint. Nobody talks about embodied carbon in concrete. Let me fix that: 🧵
Concrete = 8% of global CO2 emissions. That's more than aviation. Yet we pour 30 billion tons annually.
The culprit: Portland cement. The chemical reaction that makes it strong releases CO2. No way around it with traditional methods.
Solution 1: Supplementary cementitious materials (SCMs). Replace 30-50% of cement with fly ash or slag. Reduces emissions by 40%.
Solution 2: Carbon-cured concrete. Inject CO2 during curing. Permanently stores carbon in the concrete matrix.
Solution 3: Alternative binders. Geopolymers, magnesium-based cements. Still experimental but promising.
We've switched to SCM mixes on all projects. Same strength, 35% lower carbon, often cheaper. No-brainer.
The industry is changing. Specs that don't account for embodied carbon will be obsolete in 5 years.
